headline.main: Relief Effort Races Winter To Save Millions

lead_paragraph: Sixty Afghan refugees worked in a dusty warehouse this morning, bent under backbreaking sacks of wheat, toiling like men building a levee against a flood, racing to keep two million fellow Afghans alive. Every man was paid a nickel a sack. Every sack held 110 pounds of wheat. Every man loaded a truck by day's end. Each truck held up to 700 sacks, enough to get 400 people through the five-month winter.
abstract: International relief effort races winter to get food to some six million Afghan people on brink of starvation after years of war and drought and month of American airstrikes; effort faces number of obstacles, including poor roads, soaring fuel costs, shortage of trucks and drivers, United States bombing and poor communications within Afghanistan; Taliban is demanding more United Nations aid after first seizing World Food Program's Kabul warehouse; Pakistan has provided wheat on loan, with US vowing to replace it; photos (M)
